article:
An 'academic journal' is a peer-reviewed periodical in which scholarship
relating to a particular academic discipline is published. Academic journals
serve as forums for the introduction and presentation for scrutiny of new
research, and the critique of existing research. Gary Blake and Robert W.
Bly, The Elements of Technical Writing, pg. 113. New York: Macmillan Publishers,
1993. ISBN 0020130856 Content typically takes the form of articles
presenting original research, review articles, and book reviews.

The term academic journal applies to scholarly publications in all fields; this
article discusses the aspects common to all academic field journals. Scientific
journals and journals of the quantitative social sciences vary in form and
function from journals of the humanities and qualitative social sciences; their
specific aspects are separately discussed.
